intro: Acacia obtusifolia, commonly known as the soft-leaved wattle, is a shrub native to South Australia. It is characterized by its narrow, ovate leaves that are usually covered in a fine layer of white hairs. The plant produces yellow globular flowers in late summer, which are clustered in spikes. It thrives in well-drained soils and is drought-tolerant, making it suitable for arid and semi-arid environments. The species is also valued for its ornamental appeal and ability to stabilize soil in degraded areas.

This plant is commonly found in the arid and semi-arid regions of these Australian states. It thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is often seen in open woodlands and shrublands. Acacia obtusifolia is well adapted to the harsh climatic conditions of its native range. Its distribution is closely associated with the inland areas of eastern Australia.
